TopicTitle: Tips for a duna lander/ascent vehicle?

Articles.Content:
I'm working on a Duna mission but my lack of interplanetary experience is becoming quite apparent through my progress.

One particular question I have: how much delta-v would it take to get from the surface to orbit on Duna?

(Thanks in advance! ![:D](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_cheesy.gif))

**Edited <time datetime="2015-07-29T23:15:05Z" title="07/29/2015 11:15  PM" data-short="8 yr">July 29, 2015</time> by Mrsupersonic8**

dV: dV map shows 1200-1800 and it isn't lying. It's close to 1300 range if your ship has a reasonable aero and TWR.

General tip:

1. Don't be too afraid. If you have landed on Mun multiple times, then the gap is smaller than you thought.

2. Use airbrakes (I mean the part, not the general technique of aerobrake). Otherwise you'll almost for sure need to burn to land, and that costs fuel.

3. Return transfer may cost more dV if you want to return right away. Take that into account.

Otherwise it isn't too much different from what you already learned to land on Kerbin moons.

I'll recommend a dv of 2000-2200 if you're going to do something useful on Duna. The ascent will cost around 1500, but you need to deorbit as well, and a bit if maneuvering, plane changes and such will also cost a bit. 

Put airbrakes for the initial entry, and plenty of chutes for the descent. Also don't count on chutes alone for the actual landing, you'll probably need a \*very\* short burn to slow you those last few m/s before touchdown. Just a 2-5 second burn should do, but it will also take a little from your dv budget. 

And: better safe than sorry. 

I've just rebuilt my lander to have ~2500 dv. That allows for a short hop or two to make a couple of science measurements before I have to return to the mothership in orbit and refuel. 

Good luck.
I've found that by using parachutes, most of my Mun landers can be used on Duna, as virtually all of the fuel you would use just for landing on Mun is available for the ascent on Duna.

My solution for a Duna landing: nuclear engines. 720 fuel and two nuclear engines did it (nuclear drives lose some ISP in Duna's atmosphere, but the fuel savings are still substantial). The lander was pretty clunky, because LV-N's don't like to mount radially, but the fuel saved was worth the work in the VAB.

My big gripe with Duna right now is that the game updated one night while my ship was en route--and the sensory computing nose cone turned into a fly-by-wire avionics hub. Thereby depriving me of atmospheric scans. I call this the "Update Kraken"..... ![:)](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_smiley.gif)

This is a modified Mun lander, which is capable of getting back into Duna orbit and back to Kerbin.

I made a swallow descend and I was able to deploy my drogue parachutes, but I had to burn some 600 m/s to slow down and the regular chutes did almost nothing. Then again, I've landed at some 3,000 meters ASL. Maybe landing lower might make the parachutes useful.

EDIT: Of course, as part of your lander you can have an ore refinery at the bottom, which you leave behind when returning to Kerbin. That way you don't have to worry about fuel for the return trip.

This. In fact, if you do mun/minimus ascents and then straight back to Kerbin, the same lander will work for both missions. My current Duna mission did that, and there's no problems *with the lander.*

The cruise stage? Hell yes there's an issue, but that's another story. One involving random explosions. The lander made it back into orbit just fine.
